Introduction

Sturge-Weber syndrome (SWS) is a congenital neurocutaneous disorder characterized by facial capillary malformation (ie, nevus flammeus, or port-wine stain) in the distribution of the first or second branches of the trigeminal nerve (

figure 1
).  In addition, capillary-venous malformations involving the brain and eye can lead to clinically significant neurologic and ophthalmologic findings.

Pathogenesis and risk factors



SWS occurs due to a somatic mutation in the GNAQ gene during early embryogenesis.  The GNAQ gene encodes an intracellular signaling protein involved in early embryonic capillary development.  Persistent embryologic vasculature causes vascular malformations in the skin, leptomeninges, and eye.  Although the exact mechanism is unclear, impaired venous drainage is thought to lead to tissue ischemia and atrophy, resulting in the characteristic cutaneous, neurologic, and ophthalmologic findings in SWS.



Because the mutation occurs after the zygotic stage, it is not heritable.  Therefore, a family history of SWS does not increase the risk for disease, and there are no modifiable risk factors for SWS.

Clinical presentation



The clinical presentation of SWS primarily involves the cutaneous, neurologic, and ophthalmologic systems.

Cutaneous



Cutaneous manifestations of SWS include a facial capillary malformation, or port-wine stain, in the distribution of the first or second branches of the trigeminal nerve.  The port-wine stain may extend to the contralateral side of the face or the neck, trunk, and extremities.  The skin manifestation is apparent at birth and darkens with age.  Vascular ectasias typically develop later in life, causing a nodular appearance with underlying soft tissue overgrowth (

image 1
).  By adulthood, most patients have significant nodularity and hypertrophy throughout the port-wine stain.  Size and location can be indicators of deeper leptomeningeal involvement.  However, in the majority of cases, a facial port-wine stain is an isolated finding at birth, and patients do not develop signs of SWS.

Neurologic



Neuologic manifestations most commonly include leptomeningeal capillary-venous malformations on the same side as the port-wine stain.  Increased vascularity leads to leptomeningeal thickening and discoloration.  The occipital and parietal lobes are most commonly affected, and the underlying cortical atrophy and calcifications may form over time, likely due to venous stasis (ie, dystrophic calcification).  Clinical features include:



  • Seizures:  Seizures can develop in early childhood and are often the first sign of SWS.  In addition, many patients with seizures develop hemiparesis of the contralateral side, which leads to hemiatrophy.  Progressive loss of motor function occurs over time, likely due to restricted blood flow (ie, recurrent thrombotic events with the leptomeningeal capillary-venous malformation itself).
  • Neurodevelopmental impairment:  The rate of cognitive decline varies, but the majority of patients develop progressive intellectual disability, developmental delay, and behavioral problems.
  • Visual field defects (
    figure 2
    ):  Such defects can occur due to leptomeningeal capillary-venous malformations affecting the occipital lobes and optic tracts, and homonymous hemianopia is most common (
    figure 3
    ).

Ophthalmologic



Ophthalmologic manifestations of SWS include:



  • Glaucoma:  This occurs in approximately 50% of patients.  Episcleral capillary-venous malformations can impede aqueous humor flow through the anterior chamber angle (angle between the iris and the cornea) (
    figure 4
    ), leading to increased intraocular pressure (IOP) and progressive optic nerve damage (
    figure 5
    ).  Clinical manifestations include signs of corneal edema, including tearing (ie, epiphora), photophobia, blepharospasm, and conjunctival erythema.  Retained aqueous humor stretches the sclera and cornea (ie, enlarged globe) and causes cupping of the optic nerve.  Increased IOP can also cause the capillary-venous malformation to appear more erythematous.  Congenital glaucoma is most common, although patients can develop glaucoma as adults.
  • Choroidal and conjunctival capillary-venous malformations.
  • Heterochromia (ie, irises with different colors).

Diagnosis



In cases of suspected SWS (eg, infant or young child with facial port-wine stain, seizures, and glaucoma), diagnostic evaluation includes demonstration of leptomeningeal enhancement with underlying cortical atrophy and calcifications on imaging, typically on an MRI of the brain with contrast (

figure 6
).  However, leptomeningeal capillary-venous malformation may not be apparent on imaging in infancy; therefore, the diagnosis cannot be excluded by a normal MRI of the brain in the first few months of life.  GNAQ mutation can be confirmed via genetic testing of affected tissue but is not required for diagnosis.

Differential diagnosis



The differential diagnosis for SWS includes other neurocutaneous disorders, such as:



  • Tuberous sclerosis:  Characterized by hypopigmented ash-leaf spots, angiofibromas (ie, malar erythematous papules), and shagreen patches (flesh-colored plaques on the back).  As in SWS, in tuberous sclerosis, seizures and intellectual disability are common.
  • Neurofibromatosis type I (
    figure 7
    ):  Characterized by intellectual disability and seizures.  Cutaneous manifestations include multiple, large cafÃ© au lait macules; freckling; and neurofibromas, not a nevus flammeus.
  • Neurofibromatosis type II:  Characterized by bilateral vestibular schwannomas.  Cutaneous manifestations include cutaneous plaques and tumors.  Cataracts, not glaucoma, are common.


Although not a neurocutaneous syndrome, Klippel-Trenaunay syndrome is characterized by extensive capillary-venous malformations involving the extremities and trunk and must be distinguished from SWS.  Affected limbs become hypertrophic, not atrophic, as in SWS.  Lymphatic malformations can occur, and neurologic involvement is not expected.

Management



Management of SWS is supportive and involves a multidisciplinary approach, as follows:



  • Cutaneous:  Laser therapy (eg, pulsed dye laser) may be considered for cosmetic concerns.
  • Neurologic:  Antiepileptic drugs are often required, and breakthrough seizures are common.  Surgical resection of epileptogenic tissue may be required for intractable seizures.  Patients should be referred for physical and occupational therapies to preserve neurodevelopmental outcomes.
  • Ophthalmologic:  Routine ophthalmologic examinations are required for prompt detection of increased IOP with tonometry and choroidal capillary-venous malformations with funduscopy.  Increased IOP can often be managed with topical medications (eg, timolol, latanoprost).  Surgical intervention may be considered in refractory cases.

Prognosis



The prognosis of SWS varies, depending on the extent of neurologic involvement and age at seizure onset.  Adequate seizure control is often an indicator of a favorable prognosis.  Glaucoma can lead to complete vision loss without treatment.

Summary



Sturge-Weber syndrome (
